Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Towards Control of Photo-Induced Charges in Chiral Nanocomposites via Optical Spin-Orbit Interactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical: The research component of this CAREER award aims to understand the photo-induced electrical energy flows in chiral nanocomposite materials where nonlinear optical phenomena are observed at unprecedented low light intensities (<1 W/cm^2) stemming from the appreciable photo-induced magnetic fields and the interactions between nanoparticles. These effects, associated with optical spin-orbit interactions, are theoretically underestimated and not well understood; refining numerical models so that they properly estimate the measured intensity-dependent and polarization-dependent processes is a priority in this project. Samples of partially-metal-coated dielectric nanospheres are subsumed in transparent conducting polymers and assembled electrophoretically and with external magnetic-field processing techniques. Scattering, transient absorption, electrical, and magnetic field measurements characterize the modified nanoparticle alignment and the low-frequency charge transport that occurs in the surrounding conducting polymer.
Non-technical: The project addresses basic research issues in a topical area of materials science with technological relevancy. Nanocomposite materials provide a platform for new optoelectronics, solar harvesting, and photocatalysis applications. The educational activities of this project are designed to attract, train, and retain creative, resourceful students of all backgrounds, with special emphasis on those attending public schools in the outer New York boroughs of Queens and the Bronx. Research opportunities for highly motivated pre-college students, professional Master's students, and international collaborators address the need for scientific training prior to and outside of a doctoral program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Interest in the topic of chiral plasmonics has grown in recent years. To investigate the chiral scattering dynamics and chiral interactions, the PI has focused on three primary higher-order phenomena associated with scattering: the inverse Faraday effect, dipole-dipole interactions associated with plasmon radiation, and Lorentz forces.  These nonlinear effects lead to measurable low-frequency or time-averaged changes in the light scattering and voltages in plasmonic and nanocomposite materials. The PI has focused on oblique and asymmetric geometries that yield optically-induced surface currents with angular momenta and nonzero time-averaged forces. Our understanding of these time-averaged plasmon Lorentz forces are relevant to visualizing, realizing, and controlling the photovoltages on nanostructures, the self-assembly and mechanical dynamics of nanoparticles, and the fundamental phenomena associated with photon drag. Two additional branches of study with this grant have involved: investigations of the magnetophoretic effects of PEDOT:PSS and investigations of light-induced Marangoni flows in nanocolloids. 

Through partnerships with local high school science programs and organizations such as Ghetto Film school and Queens College College Now, the PI has also engaged with hundreds of high school students.  A couple of students conducting research projects with the PI have won awards at the International Science and Engineering Fair. With colleagues, the PI has also initiated and organized a new Gordon Research Conference on Plasmonically Powered Processes which has drawn over 120 scientists in 2017 and 2019 to study the biochemical implications and physical mechanisms associated with plasmon decay. This CAREER award has provided opportunities to advance and disseminate knowledge related to  the optical, thermal, chemical, mechanical, and electrical behavior of plasmons. This knowledge is relevant to  future applications of light sensors and heat harvesting, knowledge that may also contribute to the future development of electronics and electronics recycling.
